title: Game Theory – Repeated vs Single‑Shot Games
description: See how repetition (δ) changes incentives and supports cooperation.

questions.question: A single‑shot game:
options: Is played once; no future repercussions
questions.explanation: No future interactions → short‑term incentives dominate.

questions.question: δ (delta) represents:
questions.explanation: Higher δ = more weight on the future.

questions.question: Cooperation in repeated games is more likely when:
questions.explanation: High δ makes future rewards/punishments salient.

questions.question: Tit‑for‑Tat works by:
questions.explanation: It mirrors the opponent’s previous move.

questions.question: When δ → 1, players are:
questions.explanation: They value future almost as much as present.

questions.question: A finite, known‑horizon repeated PD tends to unravel by:
questions.explanation: Reasoning from the last period induces defection backward.

questions.question: Which is FALSE about repeated games?
options: They depend on expectations about the future
questions.explanation: Uncertainty may remain; repetition doesn’t eliminate it.

questions.question: Real‑world example of repeated interaction fostering cooperation:
options: Daily pricing among airlines on the same route
questions.explanation: Frequent interactions can avoid destructive price wars.
